column1: intrainingdoc 160416956802 "2017-05-07 20:40:31 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160416956802/why-medical-school-is-important "midwest-medblr:  This week
column2: I learned a lesson about why medical school is so important. For 4 years
column3: we cram everything into our heads
column4: a little about every specialty. In the end
column5: we all just can’t wait to specialize in our own fields and not have to remember the majority of other stuff we memorized. We can always just consult someone else if we need help right? Well… What if you didn’t recognize the underlying problem in the first place? This week on neurology
column6: we had a 27 year old woman who was admitted overnight for severe headache. They ended up doing a brain MRI
column7: which showed several small diffusion weighted defects in the posterior brain consistent with strokes. We were asked to see her in the morning for evaluation of “strokes”. I was asked to read her chart and go see her. I thought it was a little odd that a healthy 27 year old had strokes
column8: but you never know. I start reading up and see that her systolic blood pressure has been above 160 all night. They were allowing some degree of permissive hypertension for her strokes. Her creatinine was 1.4. They also assumed this was because of her elevated blood pressures. Finally
column9: there was protein in her urine. I keep reading and notice she is 4 days postpartum. I haven’t even seen the patient yet and put the pieces together in my head. Elevated blood pressure
column10: severe headache with visual scotomas
column11: elevated creatinine
column12: protein in the urine
column14: this person has preeclampsia with severe features and needs to be started on a magnesium drip immediately! I want to go into Ob/Gyn
column15: so naturally I was a little excited that I recognized this. I immediately went to my 70 year old attending and told him this. He looked surprised
column16: and I could tell he probably hadn’t thought about this disease in decades since usually they are admitted to ob/gyn and not neurology. He asked me to call the ob/gyn that was on. Within a few hours
column17: she was seen and started on a magnesium drip for preeclampsia with severe features. My attending and I went to radiology and had them re-read the scan. She had PRES not strokes. This woman could have gone home on aspirin
column19: and a statin with neurology follow-up and had a seizure a day later from full blown eclampsia. In the end
column20: I learned about how one person going down the rabbit hole of one diagnosis can lead to a series of several providers going down it as well. It was a shining moment for me as a medical student
column21: not going to lie. But it also showed me the importance of being well read and not shutting out my mind to other specialties. We all need to know a little about everything and when to realize our limits and consult someone else. And a lot of the time
column22: medical school is the only immersive experience we will get in many of these specialties. It matters more than just learning for the sake of the shelves. " False text

column2: check out some of my favorites below: The House of God by Samuel Shem A classic pre-medical school book. It details residency life in the 1970s. column3: I would say it is very accurate. Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story by Ben Carson. Just because I find Ben Carson incompetent as a politician does not mean I do not respect him as a doctor. He is a phenomenal pediatric neurosurgeon and this book details his story. On Doctoring: Stories
column4: Poems

With excerpts from old patient notes which I found very interesting.  And if you have an interest is something more dark: Blind Eye by James B. column1: intrainingdoc 162411366282 "2017-06-29 22:20:24 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162411366282/the-truth-behind-stereotypes "dxmedstudent: shrinkrants:  themedicalchronicles:  thedisagreeabledoctor:  While preparing for my next patient I read in her previous note that she “..is a Vietnamese immigrant who works at a nail salon.”  I stifled a laugh as I recalled Dat Phan’s comedy bit on the Vietnamese taking over the U.S. one foot at a time.  I mentally scolded myself as I tried to dismiss my racist stereotype.  Yet
column2: you cannot deny that this is one stereotype that frequently plays true.  She smiled as I entered the room
column3: remaining patient as I fumbled with the pronunciation of her name.  After exchanging pleasantries we discussed her reasons for coming in: a lingering cold and a skin lesion.  I noted that she had missed multiple appointments prior to this
column4: failing to get follow up labs from over a year ago.  She blamed this on her busy schedule
column5: caring for two children and working full-time.  For providers the chronically busy patient can seem as frustrating as the chronically sick patient. Next we proceeded into her exam.  The stigmata for bacterial infection were conspicuously absent.  I described my findings to her
column6: watching her mood deflate slightly when I explained that antibiotics would not help.  I continued to work my way down her body in a systematic exam
column7: explaining as I went.  As I came to her hands I winced.  The skin was thickened
column8: dried
column9: and cracked.  My hands began to hurt in sympathy. “Tell me about your hands
column10: ” I said. She responded in deeply accented English that her hands became like this after working with the nail chemicals all day.  “And do you like this job?” I asked. “I hate it
column11: ” she responded.  I continued to inquire why
column12: if she hated her job and it hurt her skin in such a terrible way
column13: she did not seek other employment.  “In my country I was a nurse.  But here I would have to start schooling over.  It would take twice as long because I would first have to take English classes.” She continued to explain that when coming over
column14: many Vietnamese people worked in nail salons because that is where other Vietnamese people worked.  In other words
column15: it was one of the few places they could get a foot in the door as untrained workers who barely spoke discernible English.  Suddenly the Dat Phan comedy bit seemed a lot less funny. “Why come to the U.S.?”  I asked.  “If you were a nurse in Vietnam
column16: why immigrate to a place with few job opportunities.” Her answer?  She makes more here as a nail technician than a nurse in Vietnam
column17: meaning she can send money to her family at home.  And being here gives her two teenage children a better opportunity for employment as they grow up.  In short
column18: this woman gave up a job she enjoyed
column19: to work in conditions she hates
column20: in order for her family to have opportunities she never could. Long after I wrote her note and sent her on her way
column21: my Vietnamese patient lingered in my mind.  Interestingly
column22: the more I thought the more I realized she did fit into a stereotype
column23: although I had placed her in the wrong one.  Perhaps it is partially true to think that many Vietnamese immigrants are nail technicians.  But I think the better way to look at immigrants
column25: is with the lens of selfless hope they often bring with them
column26: rather than the employment circumstances they often find themselves in.  She
column27: like the most tremendous among us
column28: gave up her life goals in order to propel her family into a new socioeconomic class.  That to me doesn’t fit the image the media promotes for immigrants
column29: but rather the image I think of when I see working class mothers struggling for their family’s sake.  And I think that stereotype
column30: an example of the best that people have to offer
column31: is a stereotype I can live with.   Reminds me of a post I saw somewhere on Tumblr: Hands up for our parents that came to America with nothing and gave us everything.   Yes to all this
column32: AND let’s be careful not to fall into the belief that it’s possible for every immigrant
column33: or every ghetto-ized person of color to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps. We need a living wage
column37: and much more for folks at all levels of our very steep pyramid.  The immigrant experience in a nutshell
column38: for those of you who aren’t from an immigrant background. " False text

column2: and while the paramedics had gotten his heart to start beating again

column7: being as sick as he is and going through the treatment he did.  He wouldn’t want this.  I’m leaving to drive there as soon as I hang up
column8: but I want you to take the tube out

column10: and if he starts to die before I get there
column11: let him go.  Don’t put the tube back in
column12: don’t start pressors

column16: but he wanted us to make and keep him comfortable
column17: instead. If my brother is ever (heaven forbid) in that same situation and I have to make a decision

column19: let his death progress as naturally as it could
column21: and accept that I may not get there in time to see him alive again
column22: but feel it is worth it so I can spare him some suffering.  Sometimes the best gift you can give a loved one is the gift of letting nature take its course. Quantity of life does not always equal quality of life.   *reblogging for the people in the back*" False text
